etymologies: Old English sceal, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zal and German soll, from a base meaning ‘owe’

notes.text: There is considerable confusion about when to use shall and will. The traditional rule in standard English is that shall is used with first person pronouns (I and we) to form the future tense, while will is used with second and third persons (you, he, she, it, they): I shall be late; she will not be there. To express a strong determination to do something, these positions are reversed, with will being used with the first person and shall with the second and third persons: I will not tolerate this; you shall go to school. In practice, however, shall and will are today used more or less interchangeably in statements (although not in questions). Given that the forms are frequently contracted (we'll, she'll, etc.), there is often no need to make a choice between shall and will, another factor no doubt instrumental in weakening the distinction. In modern English, the interchangeable use of shall and will is an acceptable part of standard US and British English

definitions: (in the first person) expressing the future tense

examples.text: this time next week I shall be in Scotland

definitions: expressing a strong assertion or intention

examples.text: you shall not frighten me out of this

definitions: used in questions indicating offers or suggestions

examples.text: shall I send you the book?

shortDefinitions: used in questions indicating offers or suggestions
